I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the  Republic  of  the  Union  of  Myanmar  for  the  Second  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  Highway 
Modernization Project. 
 
2. 
The project will (i) construct a new four-lane expressway between Bago (Bago region) and 
Kyaikto  (Mon  state)  of  about  64  kilometers  (km)  along  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  (GMS) 
East–West  Economic  Corridor  (EWEC); 1 (ii)  build  the  government’s  capacity  to  develop  and 
manage expressways that meet international standards; and (iii) ensure road safety in the Bago–
Kyaikto  corridor.  The  project  will  benefit  poor,  rural  residents  in  the    Bago–Kyaikto  corridor  by 
providing climate-resilient, safe, and more efficient connectivity between Bago and Kyaikto, and 
to other destinations in the EWEC. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Macroeconomic  context  and  impact  of  the  coronavirus  disease  pandemic.  Since 
2012 when the Government of Myanmar decided to reengage with the international community 
and initiated structural reforms, Myanmar has been aiming to achieve sustained economic growth 
through  the  market  economy,  with  strong  growth  averaging  6.4%  in  2015—2019.  In  2020, 
however, despite a moderate but recently increasing number of confirmed coronavirus disease 
(COVID-19) cases, disruptions to key economic sectors and to trade and investment flows stand 
to  derail  its  growth  trajectory,  down  from  an  original  estimate  of  6.8%  to  1.8%,  equivalent  to 
economic  losses  of  $3.3  billion.  COVID-19  may  also  slow  Myanmar’s  significant  progress  in 
poverty  reduction  because  large  poor  and  vulnerable  populations  are  least  able  to  cope.  Job 
losses, including those for returning migrants, are estimated at 1.2 millionꟷ2.1 million, and the 
number of the poor is likely to increase by 1.3 million.2 There are concerns that job losses may 
increase due to continued slowdown in Thailand and other economies. The project is expected to 
assist Myanmar’s post COVID-19 economic recovery by helping to create jobs through increased 
road transport efficiency and providing support for integrated and sustainable economic growth.  
 
4. 
Transport  sector  issues  and  opportunities.  A  key  ingredient  of  the  government’s 
strategy for economic growth has been to modernize the country’s transport system. Increasing 
infrastructure investments especially improving its highway network will enable Myanmar to take 
full advantage of its geographical location in the region and global value chains and realize its 
growth  potential.3 However,  Myanmar’s  transport  infrastructure  has  lagged  behind  the  rest  of 
Southeast Asia because of inadequate investment. Myanmar invested only about 1% of its gross 
domestic  product  during  2005–2018  in  transport  infrastructure,  while  faster-growing  Asian 
countries  invested  about  3%.  In  2017,  the  government  estimated  that  14  million  people  in 
Myanmar  lived  in  villages  that  are  physically  isolated  because  there  is  no  connecting  road,  or 
because the road is flooded or becomes muddy during the rainy season.  
 
5. 
To hasten and leverage government investment, the Ministry of Construction (MOC) had 
contracted 26 private concessionaires to manage and improve the main highways, about 5,545

km  in  total.  However,  the  concession  arrangements  currently  in  place  have  had  mixed  results 
because  of  limited  MOC  capacity  to  manage  concessionaires  including  ineffective  concession 
agreements, low toll revenues, and poor execution of operation and maintenance (O&M).4 The 
high risk of not being able to induce sufficient traffic for large capital investments has also made 
it  difficult  to  attract  upfront  private  sector  investments.  The  experience  indicates  that  an 
incremental approach which takes into account the capacity of the MOC and the risk of the traffic 
level should be pursued, starting with improving O&M arrangements where feasible. 
 
In 2012, the government removed restrictions on vehicle imports, resulting in gradually 
6.  
increased traffic on the road network. This has led to growing congestion as well as to faster road 
deterioration, resulting in a shorter useful road life, where a study estimated that only 71% of the 
national highways are paved.5 The government plans to increase transport investments to 3% of 
gross domestic product by 2030 by refocusing on the main corridors and ensuring adherence to 
international design standards to keep road conditions in a fair to good condition for the roads’ 
useful life for passenger safety. Government objectives outlined in the National Transport Sector 
Development  Master  Plan  and  the  Master  Plan  for  Arterial  Road  Network  Development  in 
Myanmar  provide  guidance  for  long-term  investments. 6  The  government’s  strategy  is  to 
modernize and improve management of the existing highway network and to develop an arterial 
highway  network  on  straighter  alignments  for  a  more  efficient  transportation,  while  avoiding 
settled areas. 
 
7. 
Greater  Mekong  Subregion  corridors.  The  GMS  corridors  are  the  backbone  of 
Myanmar’s transport system. The EWEC in particular connects Da Nang in Viet Nam with Yangon 
and its special economic zone of Thilawa, and further west to Pathein. The sections of the EWEC 
in Thailand, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic, and Viet Nam have been completed based 
on international standards, with improved border facilities. Improvements in connectivity between 
Bago  and  Kyaikto  along  the  EWEC  will  reduce  national  transport  costs  within  Myanmar  and 
improve regional connectivity with Thailand and onwards to the rest of the GMS.7 About 3,000–
11,000 vehicles per day used the segment of the EWEC in Myanmar in 2017. The traffic volume 
has been increasing since 2012, and the Myanmar segment of the EWEC is likely to reach its full 
capacity of about 15,000 vehicles per day about 2025-2030 (footnotes 3 and 5). 
 
Road safety. Most of the road corridors in Myanmar, including those in the EWEC, have 
8. 
only two lanes, with pavement condition ranging from poor to fair. Road safety is a serious issue, 
and Myanmar’s crash fatality rate is among the highest in Southeast Asia with 21 fatalities per 
100,000 inhabitants with 95% of fatalities attributable to road user behavior errors.8 Alignments 
of existing roads go through populated areas. Low design standards together with a mix of road 
users (motorized and nonmotorized vehicles, pedestrians, and animals) make it unsafe for vehicle 
speeds greater than 60 km per hour.  
 
Pro-poor focus of the project. The Bago–Kyaikto corridor across the Bago region and 
9. 
Mon state has higher poverty rate (31.0%) than the national average (24.8%). Poverty is further

aggravated by the fact that people living in rural areas along the EWEC, including those living 
along the Bago–Kyaikto corridor, cannot fully benefit from road connections because of the limited 
rural  road  network.  In  the  Bago  region  and  Mon  state  where  the  project  will  be  located,  the 
government  estimates  that  1.4  million  people  have  inadequate  rural  road  access.9 In  addition, 
these areas are also prone to floods, exasperated by climate change, damaging existing roads. 
Floods also prevent road access or result in only seasonal access, as shown by the severe flood 
of  July  2017  which  inundated  the    Bago–Kyaikto  road,  limiting  its  access  for  three  days.  The 
project  will enhance connectivity along the segment of the  EWEC between Bago and Kyaikto, 
thus benefiting the Bago region and Mon state through increased trade, tourism, and investment 
activities with other GMS countries, particularly Thailand, by bringing producers and consumers 
closer to markets and creating employment and income opportunities for people living on both 
sides of the border. In addition, about 70,000 residents along the proposed alignment will benefit 
from  access  roads  to be  paved  under  the  project  (about  25  km),  which  will  provide  direct  and 
climate-resilient access to the newly constructed expressway and other existing roads. 
 
10. 
The government’s sector strategy and the role of the proposed project. The project 
will help the government with its long-term objective to develop an arterial highway network, which 
is essential to achieving rapid economic growth. In line with the government’s Master Plan for 
Arterial Road Network Development in Myanmar (footnote 6), which includes the proposed Bago–
Kyaikto expressway, the construction of about 560 km of arterial highways has already begun. 
Another  3,290  km  of  arterial  highways  are  planned  to  be  constructed  during  2020–2030.  The 
arterial  highway  development  program  accounts  for  half  of  Myanmar’s  long-term  transport 
investment needs.  
 
The project will improve the capacity of the Bago–Kyaikto section of the EWEC, where the 
11. 
current two-lane road has high traffic volumes (para. 7). A prefeasibility study prepared by the 
Japan international Cooperation Agency (JICA) indicates that this section would reach capacity 
sometime  between  2025  and  2030.  Upgrading  the  existing  road  is  not  the  preferred  solution 
because its widening would involve large resettlement impacts, and the alignment of the existing 
road is long and winding in several areas. The proposed project will construct a new, four-lane 
Bago–Kyaikto expressway that is 32 km shorter than the current segment of the EWEC. It will 
halve  the  current  travel  time  of  110  minutes  between  Bago  and  Kyaikto  and  provide  all-year 
access to townships in the project area.  
 
12. 
COVID-19 Recovery through the Project. Creating sustained recovery opportunities will 
be  critical.  Strengthening  road  connectivity  can  play  an  important  role  on  this  front,  as  the 
proposed expressway will reduce transport time and costs; open new economic and employment 
opportunities  through  linkages  to  new  markets  and  production  centers;  and  increase  the  local 
population’s access to health, education, and other social services. In the short-term, the project 
itself will create significant construction and other ancillary jobs. Several micro, small and medium-
sized enterprises in the construction value chain will be supported. Over the medium to long-term, 
there  is  a  strong  link  between  improved  transport  and  poverty  reduction  for  inclusive  growth. 
Furthermore, improved accessibility to local and regional markets through better roads increases 
opportunities for women to participate in the labor market.

Lessons learned. The project builds on ADB’s past and ongoing experience with road 
14. 
projects in Myanmar and incorporates the following lessons from such interventions, as reflected 
in  the  project  design:  (i)  providing  road  access  with  pavement  surfacing  suitable  for  local 
challenges and conditions; (ii) improving the capacity of the local contracting industry in deciding 
package size  for contracts; (iii) ensuring that the project is implemented in a timely manner by 
managing environment and resettlement safeguards issues efficiently during project planning; (iv) 
enhancing road safety for expressway ramps at designated intercity bus stops; and (v) enhancing 
project  readiness  of  future  projects  through  fast-tracked  detailed  design  prepared  under  an 
ongoing loan (footnote 21), based on continuous discussions with the borrower. 
 
B. 
 
15. 
The project is aligned with the following impact: an arterial highway network established 
in  support  of  economic  development,  regional  economic  growth,  and  international  industrial 
competitiveness in a way that is safe, environmentally friendly, and efficient. The project will have 
the following outcome: more efficient and safer movement of goods and people between Bago 
and Kyaikto along the GMS EWEC.11  
 
16. 
Output  1:  New  Bago–Kyaikto  expressway  constructed.  The  project  will  construct 
about  64  km  of  four-lane  expressway  between  Bago  and  Kyaikto.  The  new  expressway  will 
provide an alternate route between Bago and Kyaikto, shortening the current distance by 32 km 
and  simultaneously  providing  climate-resilient  access  for  this  flood-prone  area.  The  proposed 
expressway is also the first greenfield expressway in Myanmar and will be fully access controlled. 
A  2.3  km  New  Sittaung  Bridge  across  the  Sittaung  River  is  proposed to  be  constructed  under 
JICA’s  parallel  cofinancing  loan,  not  administered  by  ADB.12 The  construction  supervision  and 
implementation  support  (CSIS)  consultant  to  be  financed  by  ADB  will  help  the  Department  of 
Highways under the MOC and the project management unit (PMU) implement the project.

17. 
Output  2:  Capacity  of  Ministry  of  Construction  for  expressway  management 
enhanced. This output will focus on developing and implementing a new scheme for expressway 
and toll road management for the MOC.13 The CSIS consultant will propose (i) routine, periodic, 
and  emergency  maintenance  activities  for  a  sustainable  road  asset  management  and  (ii) 
enhanced concession arrangements for O&M. The project will be used as a demonstration case, 
to be scaled up for the country’s highway network managed by the MOC. With ongoing OPPP 
support,  possible  schemes  for  wider  private  sector  financing  (i.e.,  capital  investment)  will  be 
pursued.14 
 
18. 
Output 3: Road safety for Bago–Kyaikto corridor improved. This output will focus on 
improving safety along the project corridor, building on the road safety program being finalized 
under  an  ongoing  technical  assistance  (TA)  that  focuses  on  establishing  a  foundation  for  a 
sustainable  road  safety  regime  for  Myanmar.  This  output  will  (i)  implement  an  innovative 
community-based road safety program, focusing on road user education and social enforcement 
to achieve a sustainable long-term safe environment for road users and the local community; (ii) 
include the essential road safety engineering elements in the detailed design; and (iii) implement 
innovative safety measures (see Box in para. 20) during construction phase together with road 
safety education for consultants and contractors. Equipment necessary for the MOC to improve 
road safety will be procured under the project.15  
 
C. 
 
19. 
Since 2012, transport has been a main pillar of ADB’s reengagement strategy in Myanmar. 
ADB’s strategy has focused on the GMS corridors and on rural–urban links.16 ADB has financed 
road improvement projects in the Ayeyarwady delta and on the Eindu–Kawkareik section of the 
EWEC.17 ADB has also prepared a strategic review of the transport sector and provided TA to 
reform sector institutions and build their capacity in road asset management and safety.18 It also 
provided assistance to prepare the National Strategy for Rural Roads and Access (footnote 9). 
Currently, through its Office of Public-Private Partnership (OPPP), ADB is supporting the MOC 
with its public–private partnership (PPP) capacity, including designing more effective concession 
arrangements. As a result, the MOC has initiated application of road asset management tools in 
the  DOH,  while  the  Ministry  of  Transport  and  Communications  has  implemented  its  Myanmar 
railways reform agenda in its first project for ADB financing.19 ADB is also supporting the MOC to 
increase private sector participation in sustainable O&M activities, through assistance in drafting 
concession agreements with sustainability objectives.20

The government has requested ADB’s further assistance in developing the country’s main 
20. 
road corridors, particularly the EWEC, and improve their management. As the first response, in 
2018, ADB approved the GMS Highway Modernization Project to address traffic demand up to 
2025.21 The GMS Highway Modernization Project included the preparation and rehabilitation of 
the  Yangon–Pathein  and  Bago–Thilawa  sections  of  the  EWEC,  which  were  in  poor  condition. 
ADB also approved a rural roads project in 2019, which will allow rural residents in Ayeyarwady 
and  Magway  regions  to  use  a  national  highway  year-round. 22 With  the  long-term  vision  and 
relationship with the government, it has requested ADB to support this first greenfield expressway 
in Myanmar. The design fully takes into account the government’s lack of experience (para. 5) 
and has drawn from ADB’s experience in other Asian countries, including expressway projects in 
Viet Nam, and builds on the policy dialogue between ADB and the government on the transport 
sector, together with PPP capacity-building activity for the MOC through ADB’s OPPP.23 24 The 
project will also generate a synergy with a proposed GMS: Cross-Border Livestock Health and 
Value  Chains  Improvement  Project,  now  under  preparation.  The  noteworthy  features  of  the 
project are summarized below. 
 

Box: Noteworthy Features of the Project 
•  The  project  areas  have  higher  poverty  incidence  31%  than  the  national  average  24%,  with  a 
population density of 146 persons per square km almost twice as high as the national level of 76. 
The project during construction as well as during its life will bring highly pro-poor benefits. 

•  Myanmar will be able to deepen its share in the agriculture and other value chains, of average 23% 
of annual GDP, through greater regional trade broadly in GMS and particularly between Myanmar 
and Thailand, about $3 billion in 2019 with expected yearly average increase of 40%. 

•  With traffic demand forecast to rise sharply, as seen over 3-fold increase between 2012–2018, there 
will be a serious deterioration of the traffic environment. The project will address these issues by 
constructing the access-controlled expressway that meets quality infrastructure principles, including 
climate resilience and introducing noise barriers and 102 underpasses to ensure residents’ mobility. 
•  Construction methods that are new to Myanmar (for example, Incremental Loading Method) will be 

pursued for soft-soil treatment, which will also enhance climate resilience. 

•  Road safety will be of paramount concern and focus, with third worst fatality rate in southeast Asia, 
introducing real-time surveillance and emergency response systems. More women (at least 50%) 
will be involved in and benefit from road safety awareness training. 

•  With the expected spike in trade and logistics promotion, as shown above, it is vital to improve asset 

management capacity—another focus area of the project. 

•  Project aims to propose a sustainable O&M model for toll highways for the MOC to increase private 
sector participation, including possible PPP arrangements, which are also replicable for ongoing toll 
road concession agreements. Secured toll booths will be built.

DUE DILIGENCE 

Technical 

 
A. 
 
The  technical  due  diligence  undertaken  during  project  preparation  confirmed  that  the 
25. 
project’s technical designs are appropriate for roads in the project locations, including alignment, 
cross-sections, structural characteristics, soft soil treatment, road safety provisions, and projected 
traffic  volume.  Appropriate  measures  have  been  identified  to  improve  climate  and  disaster 
resilience  (para.  40).  Pavement  structures  of  the  proposed  four-lane  expressway  have  been 
selected to enable a 10-year useful life for asphalt concrete, with 100-year flood (a flood with a 
100  year  frequency)  applied  for  all  river  crossings  and  for  all  major  drainage  structures.  The 
underlying traffic projection is based on present traffic volumes, with growth rates that consider 
the  likely  rapid  increase  in  traffic  expected  as  Myanmar’s  economy  continues  to  develop.  All 
materials  used  in  road  construction  are  locally  procured  except  for  bitumen,  road  signs,  road 
furniture, noise barriers, and reinforcement steel in concrete. 
 
B. 
 
26. 
Economic viability. The project is economically viable. The main benefits of the project 
under output 1 are reduced vehicle operating costs and shorter travel times. The project will also 
likely  generate  road  safety  cost  savings  under  output  3.  The  overall  economic  internal  rate  of 
return of the project is estimated to be 14.9%.25 In addition, as a part of the GMS EWEC, the 
project provides one of the last-mile transport links to Thailand, with expected increased trade in 
goods, tourism, and investment. 
 
Financial viability. It is anticipated that with a new O&M scheme to be implemented under 
27. 
output 2, the project will generate revenue from revised tariffs and increased traffic volumes. The 
revenue, however, is expected not to be sufficient to cover the significant capital investments, and 
both the financial net present value (NPV) and financial internal rate of return for the project are 
negative.  But  the  NPV  during  the  O&M  period  is  still  greater  than  the  total  O&M  costs  of  the

C. 
 
Under  MOC’s  current  O&M  scheme,  the  sustainability  of  the  project  would  depend  on 
28. 
general  budget  appropriations  for  road  maintenance,  which  are  for  those  roads  not  under 
concessions. The DOH receives fiscal allocations of about $125 million annually from the central 
and  regional  governments  for  road  O&M.  This  allocation  is  considered  sufficient  to  maintain 
current road and traffic conditions; however, there is a risk of an increased maintenance backlog. 
Strengthening the capacity of the MOC as an institution which operates the wider road network in 
Myanmar and enhancing the expressway and toll road management scheme, including revising 
and  updating  toll  fees,  are  critical  to  support  the  long-term  operational  efficiency  and  financial 
sustainability of the new project expressway. 
 
D. 
 
29. 
Procurement.  Strategic  procurement  planning  was  carried  out  to  identify  procurement 
risks,  develop  mitigating  measures,  review  procurement  options,  and  agree  on  fit-for-purpose 
procurement arrangements. The procurement risk is rated high since the DOH lacks capability 
and  will  depend  on  international  consultants  for  the  preparation  of  the  detailed  design, 
procurement, and project implementation support. The capacity development in procurement will 
be provided by the consultant through day-to-day assistance and trainings. Value for money will 
be achieved by (i) selecting the CSIS consultant through advance action under the quality- and 
cost-based selection method with 90% weight assigned to quality; and (ii) procuring the civil works 
package through open competitive bidding, where one civil works contract is split into five lots, 
taking into account engineering considerations and the size and complexity of road sections, and 
where bidders are permitted to bid for a single lot or combination of lots based on their technical 
capacity and availability of financial resources. 
 
30. 
Institutional  capacity.  The  procurement  management  risk  is  rated  high.  Although  the 
DOH  has  made  progress,  it  is  still  dependent  on  international  consultants  for  implementation 
support for ongoing projects. Capacity development will be continued under the proposed project 
with  consultant  support,  initially  through  day-to-day  assistance  and  trainings.  In  parallel  to  the 
project,  ADB  will  strengthen  the  DOH’s  capacity  in  safeguards,  procurement,  and  contract 
management through day-to-day assistance and capacity-building workshops. 
 
31. 
Financial  management.  The  premitigation  financial  management  risk  is  substantial, 
mainly because of weaknesses in government-wide financial management systems and limited 
capacity of the DOH in financial reporting, and internal audit. Through the strengthened PMU, the 
DOH  will  manage  project  financial  management  arrangements,  including  implementation  of 
project-specific financial management actions to mitigate the risks. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy 
(1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed with the government and the MOC. 
The specific policy requirements, proposed risk mitigating actions, and supplementary measures 
are described in the project administration manual. 26

Poverty. The average poverty rate of four townships (Bago, Waw, Thanatpin, and Kyaikto) 
32. 
close to the proposed road is 31.0%, higher than the national average of 24.8% for Myanmar in 
2017.27 While the average national poverty rate fell significantly from 32.1% in 2015 to 24.8% in 
2017, the decline in poverty rate in the project areas was marginal in the same period. The total 
number of households that will be directly benefited by the project is estimated to be 13,100 with 
about 69,000 people, 52% of whom are women. The new road will halve the travel time (currently 
110  minutes)  between  Bago  and  Kyaikto,  facilitate  the  transport  of  commodities,  and  promote 
economic development of the project states and GMS. Further, direct poverty alleviation benefits 
of  the  project  are  expected  to  derive  from  improved  access  to  services  (such  as  health  and 
education), employment  opportunities,  and  markets.  Indirect  poverty  alleviation  will  result  from 
the project’s contribution to economic development through lower transport costs resulting from 
reduced travel times and vehicle operating costs. 
 
Gender.  The  project  is  categorized  as  having  some  gender  elements  for  gender 
33. 
mainstreaming.  A gender action plan was prepared to identify  specific programs and activities 
where  participation  of  women  can  be  promoted. 28 The  project  will  address  marginalization  of 
women in training through specific targets for women in project training activities. For villages in 
the  project  areas,  participation  of  women  will  be  actively  promoted  in  consultation  activities, 
HIV/AIDS, and the Human Trafficking Awareness and Prevention Program (footnote 26), as well 
as livelihood restoration activities for households affected by land acquisition. The participation of 
women  in  capacity  development  programs  in  government  agencies  responsible  for  project 
implementation  and  operation  will  also  be  ensured  through  targets  in  training  for  project 
management and crash data collection and analysis provided under outputs 1 and 3. The project 
will also mitigate risks to women posed during the construction period. Risks of sexual harassment 
and  gender-based  violence  will  be  reduced  through  grievance  redress  mechanisms  that  are 
accessible  and  oriented  towards  women,  as  well  as  public  awareness  campaigns  on  what 
constitutes gender-based violence and sexual harassment and where women can go for support. 
 
34. 
HIV/AIDS  and  human  trafficking.  The  project  could  face  increased  risks  of  HIV/AIDS 
and sexually transmitted infections as well as human trafficking. The risks are associated with the 
construction phase as a result of the influx of construction workers and camp followers (including 
sex workers) and low levels of awareness of risk prevention, as well as during the operation phase 
of the completed project because of increased mobility. To mitigate these risks, the project will 
implement  the  Human  Trafficking  Awareness  and  Prevention  Program.  The  program  will  be 
implemented by a service provider under the CSIS consultant. The main activities of the program 
will  include  (i)  raising  awareness  of  local  communities  and  high-risk  groups  using  behavioral 
change communication, (ii) improving access to medical services, (iii) raising the capacities of the 
stakeholders, and (iv) mobilizing local peer educators. The civil works contractors will be required 
to provide HIV/AIDS awareness and prevention training for their workers. 
 
35. 
Safe working under COVID-19 conditions. The impact of COVID-19 is evolving, and the 
implementation of the project will be responsive and flexible in meeting emerging needs and new 
guidance.  The  project  will  strictly  follow  government  guidance  on  safe  working  in  COVID-19 
conditions, adhering to the most robust medical and scientific advice. The project parties will be 
required  to  incorporate  emerging  international  construction  best  practice  on  distancing  (where 
practical  for  works  of  this  nature),  implementation  methodologies,  effective  use  of  forced  air 
ventilation systems, and personal protective equipment. This is vital for work in deep trench and 
other confined spaces, where the risk of transmission is high.

accounting  and  reporting  procedures  lead  to  risk  of 
erroneous  and  fraudulent  financial  data  and  misuse  of 
project  funds  and  assets;  delay  in  project  financial 
reporting (quarterly progress reports and annual audited 
project  financial  statements  submissions);  and  delay  in 
management  information  on  project  performance  (cost 
overruns, disbursement and/or payment requirements). 

External  auditor’s  opinions  provided  on  project  financial 
statements are not in line with ADB requirements. There 
is no independent assurance on the use of loan proceeds. 

Weak  capacity  of  the  government  in  procurement  and 
contract management leads to less qualified contractors 
and construction delays.
